Augmented Reality as the Future of Net Art

By Winnie Liang

Website



Disciplines

Key Words
Art and Design: Interactive Arts Augmented Reality
Art and Design: Interdisciplinary Arts and Media Digital World
Digital Humanities Smartphone and Mobile Device Applications
Film and Media Studies: Visual Studies Superimposed Installations
Computer Sciences: Graphics and Human-Computer Interfaces Social Media
Communication: Communication Technology and New Media Video Games
Communication: Mass Communication
Communication: Social Media


Abstract

Augmented reality has been explored by many museums and artists. The ability to create a form inside of the digital world and place it into the real world using a small device like phones is already something amazing. As technology grows more and more, it will be even easier to connect the digital and real world. Products like Spectacles by Snapchat, glasses that bring augmented reality into the simple form of glasses, will become more widespread.

There are countless other ways that augmented reality can be used. Tools like the World Wildlife Fund (WWF) augmented reality application is used to learn Biology, an example being the watershed and how other elements can affect it. Games like Pokémon Go have also been a big catalyst in reimagining the limits of what a game can be. There are also many different ways augmented reality already exists as an art form. In addition, the internet brings a novel connection to artworks through augmented reality. The relationship between augmented reality and art can be explored through superimposed installations, site-specific installations, and games that utilize real locations and augmented reality. In conclusion, augmented reality has the ability to become the future of net art.


Into Augmented Reality

INTRODUCTION

The development of augmented reality began with the first head-mounted display in 1968 by Harvard professor, electrical engineer, and computer scientist Ivan Sutherland, recognized as the “father of computer graphics” and for contributing to building Sketchpad. In 1990 Boeing researching Tom Caudell coined the term “augmented reality.” Through this, USAF Armstrong’s Research Lab’s Louis Rosenburg created one of the first functional augmented reality systems called the “Virtual Fixtures” in 1992. This system was meant for military personnel to control and guide machinery virtually for US Air Force pilot training2.

In the theater production called Dancing in Cyberspace (1994) by writer and producer Julie Martin, augmented reality was brought to the entertainment industry for the first time. Acrobats were placed next to virtual objects on a physical stage to perform. Augmented reality also started reaching popular media in 1998 when sports-vision first integrated the yellow yard marker for NFL games. Although it has been used for more than two decades, many people do not know that it is a form of augmented reality. Currently, augmented reality has been evolving at a very fast rate, shown in social media and entertainment, games, artworks, and phone applications2.

SOCIAL MEDIA

Snapchat, Instagram, TikTok, and other social media applications have created a new age of “post-internet art” with their filters. By graphing out the facial features of the users of the applications, images can be superimposed onto the faces and backgrounds of whatever the camera sees, digitally shown to the user on their phone or other devices with the application. This breaks the traditional way of viewing art: consumption through passive observation7.

Normally, there is a border between the artwork and the viewer. Computer-mediated realities like augmented reality break that barrier and allow for a special immersive experience for all users. Many filters do not show any instructions on how to use them, making exploration a part of the art exhibition. In an article by OneZero, author Jessica Herrington says “AR face filters allow users to try on myriad physical possibilities that are impossible in everyday life. AR allows a person to make drastic changes to their appearance without any permanence or repercussions. This is different from traditional illustration, as it is immediate, reversible, and easily shared.”

Augmented reality is also slowly entering the entertainment world of games, launched into the masses by a game in 2016.

GAMES & ENTERTAINMENT

Video games have always been a source of entertainment and an incentive for people to stay home and indulge. However, the game smartphone game Pokémon Go which was released in the summer of 2016 did the complete opposite. By bringing augmented reality to the masses, Pokémon Go created a digital world inside of our real world12. Players would travel around cities and roads to collect Pokémons and battle without players, also known as trainers.

Pokémon started as a game in 1996 about trainers who collect different types of animals and insects, called Pokémon, which were contained in small capsules9. The name Pokémon itself is a portmanteau word that combines the two words “Pocket” and “Monster”, the initial title of the franchise. Since its initial release, Pokémon has been made into an anime, or a Japanese animation series, countless games, countless CGI movies, and is currently being made into a live-action series as a Netflix exclusive4.

What makes the game Pokémon Go special from the other games is its ability to combine the real world with the digital world. Players could use their smartphones as a map to hunt down and capture Pokémon on their phones by throwing a Pokémon capsule, or a Pokéball, at the Pokémon. Trainers must be at the specific location of the Pokémon in order to catch it. In addition, by using the application, users can turn on their cameras on the game and capture it as it is superimposed into the real world shown on the screen. When moving around in real life, trainers can also check-in at different public locations to get extra supplies like more Pokéballs. You can also form teams to fight battles in gyms, placed in locations around the real world with high foot traffic.

Niantic, the software-developing company that created Pokémon Go also created an application called Harry Potter: Wizards Unite. In the game, “Harry is now a middle-aged man working for the Ministry of Magic and gives players the mission to collect magical items called “Counfoundables” that have been scattered across the Muggle, or real, world”6. Although Wizards Unite did not come close to the number of players Pokémon Go had, it was more advanced than Pokémon Go. Niantic reimagined the augmented reality experience it could give to the players. Wizards were able to encounter magical items and see them in a 360-degree view. It was also better at aligning the real world with the digital world. Instead of objects struggling to run up or go forward, Niantic was about to develop their software to be able to tell the difference.

In the future, many other games and imaginary worlds will use augmented reality to blend reality and the virtual world. As of the year 2022, there are 82 different augmented reality applications in the game section of the Google Apps Play store1. Other applications for augmented reality do not have to be for entertainment, either. It can also be used as a tool.

TOOLS

Augmented reality, although new, has already been integrated into tools to help humans. One example would be Mary Poffenroth, a Biology lecturer at San Jose State University, and her Biology-10 class. To learn more about the watershed environment, she has utilized an application made by the World Wildlife Fund (WWF) called the WWF Free Rivers. It puts the entire landscape into the hands of the user, placing it directly onto a table or even a floor. Users can go in-depth into the interactive stories of the elements and the animals that habitat of the river3.

Shopping has also been made easy using augmented reality11. The online shopping website Amazon has been using augmented reality to superimpose furniture into the real space of the customer’s homes to show how it would look in the space. It could help in many ways, from sizing all the way to color. Each product is sized and rendered to scale in the space.

To experience augmented reality for themselves and learn about the city of San Jose, San Jose State University students can be connected to the history of Japantown. Hidden Histories is a live, site-specific application used on smartphones and mobile devices. It allows the audience to take a self-guided tour around Japantown. The application is able to overlay art onto the real images of Japantown for users to travel back in time and explore the history of San Jose8.

ARTWORKS FOR CHANGE

Augmented reality has also been beneficial to spreading artworks and awareness, specifically due to climate change. Many artists have been showing what the world would look like due to the continuous melting of the ice caps. Multi-disciplinary artist Mel Chin created a digital application site-specific art piece in 2018 called Unmoored that worked specifically in New York’s Times Square. Through the smartphone or mobile devices, individuals can see boats above them that are creating their own oceanic traffic jam10. Another example of augmented reality that is used to spread awareness of climate change is an application called After Ice by the developers Ghostwheel. Using data of the NASA-projected sea levels in the 2080s, After Ice was able to simulate the water level in a 100-mile radius of New York City5

Artist Tamiko Thiel’s piece, Unexpected Growth, utilizes augmented reality to create a personal connection between the audience and the art. Their piece creates a space that looks like an abundant ecosystem of growing corals and marine life but is actually "growing" plastics and waste with fake animals like rubber ducks. His use of augmented reality blurs the lines of reality, exposing the audience to the harsh truth that is pollution. Allowing the audience to see but not interact with the art physically paints a picture of the ignorance of the masses while serving as a lens into a world that is not yet, but could become a reality13.

Understanding what climate change is causing is one thing. Being able to visualize what the future holds for our children and grandchildren seeks to invoke an emotional response from the viewer. By using augmented reality, users can visualize what the current world will look like if nothing is done.

Conclusion

Augmented reality has become a novel and unexplored land of potential. It has the ability to combine reality with the digital world, breaking the barrier of passive engagement by audiences. Through social media and video games on smartphones and mobile devices, augmented reality has been brought to the masses as a form of entertainment. Furthermore, augmented reality can be used for installation works, especially call to action.
